utterances: Geoffrey Bennett is the web producer for News & Notes, and he joined me from our studios at NPR West.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, how a middle school principal in Seattle visited all 600 of his students at home this summer.
But first, more on the Republican campaign and John McCain's choice for running mate, Alaska Governor Sarah Palin.
Dan Schnur is with us again, and he was McCain's communications director back in 2000.
He now teachers at USC here in Los Angeles.
Hi, Dan.
Hey, how are you, Madeleine?
Fine, thanks.
Well, we spoke last on Friday, when Sarah Palin was first introduced.
Since then, some potentially damaging news has come out, of course, her daughter's pregnancy, her shifting support for federal earmarks, and the bridge to nowhere.
How are you feeling today, on Tuesday?
Are you as enthusiastic?
Well, I hope that the response that I offered Friday was more analysis than advocacy.
I guess what I would say a few days later is, there is still a lot of open questions about Sarah Palin.
And as we talked about on Friday, Senator McCain took a big risk in naming someone so unknown to the ticket and hope (unintelligible) would appear to be two political objectives.
One he is clearly looking to rally the party's securities base, and it seems he has done that.
Second, he's hoping to reach out - use her to help reach out to some of Senator Clinton's supporters and other working class voters.
I think it is still an open question whether these revelations help, hurt, or don't matter in that regard.
OK.
So what we're hearing from the convention, though, is there's a lot of support for his choice, that people are rallying around the choice, at least at the convention, and among the party faithful.
And so from that perspective, has it achieved at least one of those objectives, which is rallying the base?
There's no question it has achieved that first objective.
McCain, even though he's been gradually shoring up support among conservatives, that support to a large degree has seemed very dutiful.
And now, there is much more enthusiasm, it seems, both gauged by what's going on in St. Paul, but also by his fundraising and organizing efforts.
But the real key as to whether Sarah Palin was the right choice or not is how he reaches out to those working-class voters - more accurately, how she helps him do it.
Neither Senator McCain himself or, for that matter, Senator Obama has been particularly successful reaching these voters the way Senator Clinton did in the spring.
I think, just as Barack Obama selected Joe Biden in (unintelligible) because of Biden's ability to talk to these - this key voting bloc.

That was one of the main considerations for Senator McCain's selection, but it's really only been three or four days since she was selected, and I think it's worth giving it at least a week to figure out whether the pick was a smart one or not.
Well, how does McCain then counter the idea that this was kind of a reckless decision and not a great window into his decision making ability?
How does he say to America, look, I can make good decisions, and this wasn't a reckless choice?
We are actually honorary Louisiana police officers, you know, with limited authority.
One Attila sprints over, reels in hard, and then the line goes slack.
The hook wasn't strong enough, but I think the fish was big.
It's been that kind of day at the World Carp Championship.
More than a hundred teams of two are camped along 40 miles of the St. Lawrence.
They fish for almost five days straight.
The team that catches the most total pounds of carp wins a hundred thousand dollars and two GM Colorado pickup trucks.
I am Pavel Hastik from Czech Republic.
We try catch carp.
The Czech team is launching fist-sized corn and dough balls into the river with a giant slingshot.
They're baiting.
They're (unintelligible).
Unidentified Man #1: (Foreign language spoken)
Unidentified Man #2: (Foreign language spoken)
Carp are a wily catch, but they have a bit of a sweet tooth so the bait is a big part of the strategy.
Hanning Pria(ph) of South Africa sews what look like gum balls onto fishing line.
These are called boilies and they come in flavors.
Banana, pineapple, any flavor; tutti-frutti, you name it.
There must be about a thousand flavors.
And how--I mean, do you know which one works?
I mean...
I think more anglers are caught than fish.
You know, once you get on to a flavor, you don't change over to another flavor.
So you believe in that flavor, you know.
Carp anglers are passionate.
They handle the fish with reverence and treat any wounds it may have.
Some anglers will kiss a particularly sporty carp before releasing it.
This may be strange behavior to bass or trout fishermen in the US.
David Moore of Oklahoma directs the American Carp Society, which is hosting the tournament.
He says the event will help carp catch on in this country.

Once I got into carp fishing and started catching 20-pound fish, I know I was never going to catch a 20-pound bass, and you know, they fight so much harder, and you know, it's not going to be for everybody.
You know, some people are just ingrained in that bass fishing mentality, but we see a sea change coming.
(Soundbite of water splashing)
The defending carp champion is Kurt Grabmayer of Austria.
Americans like Mike Dragone of Connecticut are considered underdogs.
But Dragone's fished the St. Lawrence before.
He says he's got home field advantage over the more practiced Europeans.
Some of them we kind of idolize over here, you know.

We've been reading their books and, you know, to be up to snuff with their abilities is a challenge for us, and with a little luck, team USA, we're hoping we come up with an upset win and show the rest of the world that we can compete on this level.
There's a bonus prize that organizers hope will seal the region's reputation as carp capital of the world.
If someone reels in a fish that breaks New York's record of 50 pounds, four ounces, they'll get a million dollars.
Now that's a carp worth kissing.
For NPR News, I'm David Sommerstein in northern New York.
This could only be NPR News.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
A day before some neighborhoods officially reopen to business, people are already trickling back into New Orleans.
That is creating challenges for the police and security forces.
Authorities have pledged to keep a tight security cordon around the neighborhoods that are off-limits, but that's turning out to be easier said than done.
NPR's Martin Kaste reports from New Orleans.
This city is a virtual ghost town, and Mayor Ray Nagin sees a silver lining in that.
As far as security is concerned, this city for the first time that anyone can probably imagine is drug-free and violence-free.
The streets of New Orleans are undoubtedly safer than they've ever been.
(Soundbite of street noise)
But even an evacuated New Orleans is not perfectly crime-free or drug-free.
In one case in our sector, there were two small meth labs that were starting literally out of dishpans.
Arnold Strong is a major with the Oregon National Guard, which is patrolling much of the city, backing up the New Orleans Police Department.
He says the Guard has found evidence of a small criminal underworld hanging on in supposedly empty neighborhoods.
There's some ongoing criminal activity.
I don't want to bias, you know, the story by saying that this is huge and it's all over, but those are the stories that come out in our evening reports.
(Soundbite of boat engine)
In the areas that are still flooded, the National Guard patrols the streets in boats piloted by Fish & Wildlife agents.
As one of the boats putters down Robert E.
Lee Boulevard, Oregon Guardsman Mike Caldwell scans the houses.
Can we get over to that one right there, ma'am, the gray two-story Tudor?
Lakeview is one of the few upscale neighborhoods that was flooded.
And although the houses themselves are no longer habitable, many of them still contain valuables, especially on the second floors.
Caldwell, who works as a police officer in private life, tries to discern the difference between storm damage and forced entry.
Now you see how the windows are all completely broken out on that one or raised.
That one there we have--I have to go in and take a look-see.
The boat nudges up to the front porch and Caldwell jumps out gingerly and peers into the house, his M-16 at the ready.
He decides the house has not been burgled, at least not since the flood, because there are no footprints in the thick mud that covers every surface.
Well, he doesn't like to be pigeonholed that way.
Dorothy Day is, on the one hand, a heroine of the pro-life movement.

And for all the tension that the pope has gotten for talking about immigration issues and climate change, it's important to consider something else he said today, and that is that he thinks that the family should be seen as a recurrent theme of this trip.
We shouldn't underestimate that.
He actually has some very traditional ideas about marriage and family.
Thanks.
That's NPR's Tom Gjelten.
